ROBERT FIELD: OK,
so today, I'm going

to talk about formaldehyde,
the S1 that's not transition.

This is a beautiful
example of simple is good because when you
look at a simple problem,

you can analyze it to death
and then be surprised.

And the surprise is incredibly
important in teaching you something about the
fundamental behavior

of molecules. And so in this case, we're
going to go through and predict

everything there is to
predict about the transition from the ground
state OF formaldehyde to the excited state, using
the kind of information that's

either available or
that you can guess. And we are going to be
surprised because we're

going to see
something that appears in the vibrational structure
of this transition, which

is unexpected and
leads us to evidence that the excited
state is non-planar.

There's a low
barrier to plenary. And so even though the
structure of the excited state

is non-planar and
would therefore require not using
C2V, we use C2V,

and we see staggering in
the vibrational structure associated with the
out-of-plane bend, which

is a universal signature of
tunneling through a barrier.

And that's a universal
signature of, whenever you have a
low symmetry form,

it's almost always associated
with a kind of level staggering

associated with tunneling
through the barrier to the high-symmetry form. And this appears again and
again in different forms.

And this is, I think, one of
the first and clearest examples that taught us a huge
amount about what to expect
and how to assemble the pieces.
So let's begin.

The first thing we do-- oh, I
should say that formaldehyde--

this transition in

electronic transmission

surprising because the ground
